block.p: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

KANE ALEXANDER, Firebird Cafe, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. This fresh-faced 23-year-old Australian, an alumnus of a homegrown production of ''Les Miserables,'' is a poised, charming, raven-haired Ken doll with a real singing voice. A protege of Les Solomon, the same impresario who introduced David Campbell, Mr. Alexander blends American and Australian show tunes into an autobiographical odyssey that carries him from a tiny village in the Outback to New York City. As ingenuous as he may appear, his interpretations are tasteful and intelligently conceived. Tonight at 9 and 11. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Also at the Firebird, tomorrow night at 9, Natalie Douglas, singer. Cover: $20; $15 minimum; at 11, Alton White, singer. Cover: $30; $15 minimum. Sunday night at 7, David Friedman, as part of songwriter's series; at 9, James Beaman, singer and impersonator. Cover: $30; $15 minimum (Stephen Holden).
A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

KANE ALEXANDER, Firebird Cafe, 363 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 586-0244. This fresh-faced 23-year-old Australian, an alumnus of a homegrown production of ''Les Miserables,'' is a poised, charming, raven-haired Ken doll with a real singing voice. A protege of Les Solomon, the same impresario who introduced David Campbell, Mr. Alexander blends American and Australian show tunes into an autobiographical odyssey that carries him from a tiny village in the Outback to New York City. As ingenuous as he may appear, his interpretations are tasteful and intelligently conceived. Tonight at 9 and 11. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Also at the Firebird, tomorrow night at 9, Natalie Douglas, singer. Cover: $20; $15 minimum; at 11, Alton White, singer. Cover: $30; $15 minimum. Sunday night at 7, David Friedman, as part of songwriter's series; at 9, James Beaman, singer and impersonator. Cover: $30; $15 minimum (Stephen Holden).

MARC SALEM, Feinstein's, at the Regency, 540 Park Avenue, at 61st Street, (212) 339-4095. Marc Salem is the mental magician who dazzled audiences at the Westside Theater in Midtown with his 1997 show ''Mind Games.'' Now, Mr. Salem, accompanied by a bass, piano and percussion trio, will be in residence at Feinstein's through Sept. 2 with ''Mind Games and All That Jazz.'' But handsome as it is, Feinstein's at the Regency may not be the ideal setting for the display of Mr. Salem's enjoyable bag of tricks. The intimacy of Feinstein's, where Mr. Salem seems to be working with a smaller palette than at the Westside Theater, detracts from the distance that enhances the aura of magic that can surround, say, a wristwatch that suddenly changes the time it displays. The jazz trio Vibrations, as pleasant and talented as it is, provides little more than a few attractive introductory numbers and a bit of musical commentary of the ''Twilight Zone'' sort. Nevertheless, Mr. Salem and his wizardry provide cool fun for hot summer nights. Fridays and Saturdays at 8:30 and 11; Sunday at 1:30; Wednesday and Thursday nights at 8:30. Cover: $40 for weekends; no cover on weekdays; dinner required for early show on weekends, with seating beginning at 6; a la carte supper menu with $20 minimum for late show; $35 for early show; Sunday brunch is $30 and cover is $30. Through Sept. 2 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

* ''OUR SINATRA,'' Blue Angel Theater, 323 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. The rising young cabaret star Eric Comstock is the mastermind behind this utterly winning tribute to Ol' Blue Eyes, which focuses on what Mr. Comstock calls the hidden gems and orphan songs that Sinatra made popular. Joined by Christopher Gines, a creamy baritone who echoes Dick Haymes and Steve Lawrence in their prime, and Hilary Kole, a perky swinger, Mr. Comstock conducts a witty and knowledgeable survey of the Sinatra canon. Mr. Comstock concentrates on the mature Sinatra and Mr. Gines on the dreamy 1940's balladeer, with Ms. Kole bridging the gap. The memorable show proves that there are still young singers good enough to keep the tradition alive. Tonight, Monday through Wednesday nights at 8; tomorrow at 2:30 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 7:30. Tickets: $50 and $55; premium ringside seating, $75 and $80 (Holden).

ARCI'S PLACE, 450 Park Avenue South, at 30th Street, (212) 532-4370. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8:30 and 11, Mark Nadler's ''Wildest Party: Songs of Decadence From the Roaring 20's,'' with opening remarks by Jack Wrangler. Also at Arci's, Monday night at 8 in July, Jim Caruso, singer, with Billy Stritch, pianist. Cover: $25; $15 minimum. Charles Cermele, singer, begins his engagement Tuesday.

BEMELMANS BAR, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, (212) 744-1600. From 5:30 to 8, Michael Devine. Beginning Tuesday, Peter Mintun. Tuesdays through Saturdays, beginning at 9:30. Through Oct. 14. No cover for early show; cover for late show: $10. No minimum; $5 cover at the bar.

CARNEGIE CLUB, 156 West 56th Street, (212) 957-9676. Cary Hoffman, with the 11-piece Carnegie Club Orchestra, plays music made famous by Frank Sinatra in the 1950's, featuring the original arrangements by Nelson Riddle. Fridays and Saturdays at 9:30 and 11 p.m. Cover: $20; two-drink ($15) minimum.

DANNY'S SKYLIGHT ROOM, 346 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 265-8133. Tonight from 9 to 1 in the piano bar, Jerry Scott. Tomorrow night from 5 to 9, Chuck Musone; from 9 to 1, in the piano bar, Mr. Scott; at 9:15, Richard Holbrook, singer, with guests Valles and Boros, comedians. Sunday night from 7 to 11 p.m., Sol Yaged and friends. Monday night at 7, ''Not Just Davyd,'' with Davyd Dean; from 8 to midnight, Chris Barrett. Cover: free to $12; $10 minimum.

DON'T TELL MAMA, 343 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 757-0788. Tonight at 8, ''The Stand-Up Comedy Experience''; at 8:30, ''Poole Party's New Comedy Night,'' stand-up with Ron Poole; Nancy Witter, host; at 11, Ron Seykell, Broadway singer, with Lennie Babbish. Tomorrow night at 6:30, Beth Valenti, singer, with Rick Jensen, pianist; at 8:30 and 10:30, ''Poole Party!,'' comedy variety show. Monday night at 9, Cindy Karp, singer, with Gerry Dieffenbach, pianist. Cover: Free to $18. Two-drink minimum. No credit cards.

HUDSON RIVER PARK'S MOONDANCE SERIES, Pier 25, North Moore Street, near West Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 533-7275. Sunday night, dancing and music begin at 6:30; West Coast swing and rhythm blues with Frankie Paris and the Cool Cats. Free.

JOE'S PUB, Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. Tonight and next Thursday through Saturday at 8:30 p.m., Sandra Bernhard, singer and comedian, in ''Songs I Sang on the Kibbutz,'' with a five-piece band. Sunday night at 8:30 and 9:30, tap and Latin music with Ayodele Casel. Tickets: $20. Monday night at 8, sneak preview of the New York International Fringe Festival. Tickets: $10.

JUDY'S CHELSEA, 169 Eighth Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 929-5410. Tonight at 8:30, Julie Reyburn, singer, in ''Fate Is Kind,'' with Mark Janas, pianist. Sunday at 2 p.m., Arthur Williams Studio presents ''Cabaret Concert''; at 5:30 p.m., the musical group Eastern Standard Time in ''The Time Is Now . . . The Songs Are Timeless.'' Monday at 10 p.m., ''Leer Mondays,'' with the Lounge-O-Leers, Ricky Ritzel and Aaron Morishita. Cover: $10 to $20; $10 minimum.

OAK ROOM, Algonquin Hotel, 59 West 44th Street, (212) 840-6800. Loston Harris Trio. Tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 11:30. Cover: $40, with dinner required for early shows Fridays and Saturdays; $15 food or drink minimum for other shows; suggested dinner arrival for early show is 7. Daryl Sherman, singer and pianist, and Dave McKenna, jazz pianist, begin a two-week engagement Tuesday.

SUPPER CLUB, 240 West 47th Street, (212) 921-1940. Tonight and tomorrow night from 8 to midnight, the Supper Club's 17-piece big band. Also, the 25-minute swing revue ''This Joint Is Jumpin' '' at 9:30 and 10:30 p.m., with Larry Marshall. Swing dance lessons every Friday and Saturday night from 11:15 to midnight in the Blue Room. Tonight, Ron Sunshine and Full Swing; tomorrow night, Yallopin Hounds, from 12:30 to 2:30 a.m. Cover: $25 before 11, $15 after.

UPSTAIRS AT ROSE'S TURN, 55 Grove Street, West Village, (212) 366-5438. Tonight and tomorrow night at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Tomorrow night at 11, ''Candy Comedy Hour.'' Sunday night at 10, Adria Malcolm, singer. Cover: $5 to $7; two-drink minimum. No credit cards.
